The slope of the velocity-time graph gives the acceleration. If the graph is a straight line, the acceleration is constant. If the graph is curved, the acceleration is changing.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the graph is a straight line with a positive slope.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the particle is accelerating.
From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, the graph is a straight line with a negative slope.
From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, the particle is decelerating.

From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, the particle is continuing to decelerate.

The slope of the graph from t = 2 to t = 3 seconds is more negative than the slope from t = 1 to t = 2 second, indicating that the acceleration is becoming more negative (i.e., the deceleration is increasing).
The particle does not undergo linear motion with gradually decreasing acceleration from 1 to 2 seconds.
